Award.AwardTitle: S3: Science Symposium to engage STEM students

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project, Science Symposium to Engage STEM Students (S Cubed), is designed to expand science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) interest and involvement of rural and Native Alaskan students through two principal linked activities: participation in the Sitka Whalefest, a non-traditional, informal science symposium, and a STEM credit course that capitalizes on the resources provided by the fest. The Whalefest features talks by nationally and internationally recognized scientists whose presentations interweave their scientific expertise with current global marine science issues. The college credit course will challenge students to analyze the nature of the links the fest creates between citizens (including themselves) and prominent marine researchers (including thinking of themselves in these roles). This project will use strategies to institutionalize this kind of learning into the small college setting and measure its potential for scaling up to larger universities. It will take science out of the classroom and engage a rural population in STEM in an innovative way.

The S Cubed project will explore the potential benefits of science symposium attendance by undergraduates from minority serving institutions, particularly those serving rural populations in Alaska and Washington. It will introduce undergraduates to the way in which science symposia/festivals make science relevant, and accessible. By developing and instituting a college course around a science symposium, this effort hopes to improve the numbers of rural and underserved students who declare STEM majors. Using upperclassman mentors, who have already declared their majors, S Cubed will investigate how the amount of time students have with professional marine scientists during the conference translates into engagement in STEM educational pathways. It will also measure how student interest in STEM disciplines during a conference translates into a declaration of a STEM major or promotes interest in a related STEM career pursuit. Primarily qualitative methods will be employed for these investigations, so that the cognitive and cultural learning processes, local and historical practices, and challenges of pedagogical design spread across social settings can be deeply understood. Ethnographic observations, interviews, and surveys will be conducted throughout the course-scaling up and refinement phases with the faculty instructors, as well as with a small focal cohort of undergraduate students throughout their participation in the course. The colleges involved in this activity include Peninsula Community College, Ilisagvik Tribal College and the University of Alaska, Southeast.

This project is funded jointly by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Biological Infrastructure and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education in support of efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Education: A Call to Action http://visionandchange.org/finalreport/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Science Symposium for STEM engagement (S-Cubed) was an Engaged Student Learning Design and Development Level 1 project, funded through the National Science Foundation's IUSE Program. S-Cubed began in September 2015, and student cohorts were enrolled in 2015, 2016, 2017 and 2018.

S-Cubed prepared community college students from rural areas, who were within their first two years of undergraduate studies, to attend a marine science symposium. In rural areas, there is less access to STEM role models and fewer opportunities (relative to urban settings) to engage in designed informal science learning (such as museums, zoos, after-school clubs, library programs, etc.) that allow learners to make explicit connections to science and engineering practices and career options (After School Alliance, 2016; Bell, Lewenstein, Shouse & Feder 2009; Barron & Bell, 2015). In this program, the students were encouraged to continue to pursue STEM careers through the integration of formal and informal learning environments - at their community college and at Sitka WhaleFest, a science festival and symposium held annually in Sitka, Alaska. 

In the S-Cubed program, students registered in their college's lower-division 2-credit class in the semester or quarter in advance of the Sitka WhaleFest Science Symposium. Students met weekly with their instructor to read and review scientific papers and journal articles and discuss the specific topics to be presented during the symposium. Students then attended the WhaleFest symposium mid-semester with an understanding of the symposium theme and with the preparation to engage with the scientific experts in small group discussions that follow each presentation session. This was a guiding principle for the combination of formal coursework and participation in Sitka WhaleFest in S-Cubed: to replicate the networking and field trip components of professional conferences in an accessible format, thereby giving the S-Cubed student participants an opportunity to engage with scientists, and with the scientific ideas to help these students envision that a career in science is attainable. 

Classes were instituted for at least one year at 5 colleges; 67 lower-division students participated in their respective college's course in the fall semester/quarter and attended WhaleFest in Sitka, Alaska in November 2015, 2016, 2017 or 2018.

Learning outcomes showed the impacts of the program for the students. S-Cubed provided motivation for further study in the sciences that came at a time when many lower-division students were questioning their commitments to their field of study. S-Cubed confirmed an existing interest in the sciences, or expanded awareness of scientific knowledge or careers if a student was not already on a science track. 26% of evaluation respondents said they newly considered a major or minor in the fields related to WhaleFest after their participation in S-Cubed. 

Students participating reported feeling more confident in discussion with scientists, noting they had learned how to engage in scientific discussionduring their coursework preparation and had questions in advance in order to engage with the scientists in person. In a separate activity, a marine tour with stations staffed by masters and doctoral level candidates, S-cubed students highly valued interacting with such students, termed near-peer mentoring, which enabled them to learn potential pathways to science careers and the types of jobs available with increasing levels of academic degrees. On a layover, students toured University of Alaska Southeast and meeting advisors there helped S-Cubed students understand the transfer process, and at least three students applied to and were accepted by 4-year universities as an outcome of the connections they initiated while participating in S-Cubed.
